update.description:
This is a retargeted version of pull request #249. This PR is aimed at the default branch instead of a prototyping branch. It also contains some changes based on reviewer feedback.

Two things still on the todo list:

1. Write more tests for the raw publications and subscriptions. It would be especially good to have tests that use multiple processes. Two sub-tests were added in 1cc9ddf but more are needed.

2. Determine whether we would rather have the `Publish(~)` implementation proposed [here](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-transport/pull-requests/249/wip-subscribe-and-publish-raw-serialized/activity#comment-51885932) which is cleaner and easier to follow, or the current implementation which is more aggressive about avoiding unnecessary deserialization.

Note that some of the reviewer feedback is being addressed separately in pull request #250, and I expect that branch to get merged first.
update.title: Subscribe and publish raw (serialized) data

content.raw:
Parameter documentation is added [here](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-transport/commits/958d88796564750351d4db15676c68846e07af1b?at=default#Linclude/ignition/transport/NodeShared.hhT113).

Hopefully it should be clear from that description that a non-existent or invalid `_topic` name will just return an empty `HandlerInfo` object, since an invalid or non-existent topic shouldn't have any handlers subscribed to it.

content.raw: I considered trying something with parameterized test fixtures, but I think it would be a lot more legwork than it's worth right now. Maybe if we have time to revisit the test suite in the future, we can work out something more elegant and comprehensive. For now, I'll just resort to copy/paste/tweaking to create the new tests.
content.html: I considered trying something with parameterized test fixtures, but I think it would be a lot more legwork than it's worth right now. Maybe if we have time to revisit the test suite in the future, we can work out something more elegant and comprehensive. For now, I'll just resort to copy/paste/tweaking to create the new tests.

content.raw: Agreed that there's a lot of duplication in the tests, we don't have enough infrastructure to do it in a better way yet. I would try to cover at least the basic functionality in the interprocess case. Of course, ideas to improve it are more than welcome.
content.html: Agreed that there's a lot of duplication in the tests, we don't have enough infrastructure to do it in a better way yet. I would try to cover at least the basic functionality in the interprocess case. Of course, ideas to improve it are more than welcome.

content.raw:
From the [doxygen documentation](https://www.stack.nl/~dimitri/doxygen/manual/autolink.html) it looks like the return value and parameter names are never needed, but the trailing `const` can sometimes be needed since it's part of the function signature and may be necessary for disambiguation. In the absence of a non-const version of the function, the trailing const can be omitted. There's also:

> For non overloaded members the argument list may be omitted.

I don't imagine this function will ever be overloaded since it has a very specific purpose, but I'll add in all of the suggested changes anyway, because it probably won't hurt anything.
content.html:
From the doxygen documentation it looks like the return value and parameter names are never needed, but the trailing const can sometimes be needed since it's part of the function signature and may be necessary for disambiguation. In the absence of a non-const version of the function, the trailing const can be omitted. There's also:

For non overloaded members the argument list may be omitted.

I don't imagine this function will ever be overloaded since it has a very specific purpose, but I'll add in all of the suggested changes anyway, because it probably won't hurt anything.

content.raw:
I can think of two solutions.

1. If the functions `Partition()` and `NameSpace()` are just meant to forward the `Partition()` and `NameSpace()` functions from `Options()`, then we just define them as a wrapped up call to `this->Options()->Partition()` and `this->Options()->NameSpace()`.

2. Alternatively, we could just remove the function declarations of `Partition()` and `NameSpace()` and allow users to access those fields by calling `Options()->Partition()` and `Options()->NameSpace()`. This shouldn't harm any users, since anyone who has attempted to call `NameSpace()` or `Partition()` up until now would have gotten a linking error at compile time.
content.html:
I can think of two solutions.

  1. If the functions Partition() and NameSpace() are just meant to forward the Partition() and NameSpace() functions from Options(), then we just define them as a wrapped up call to this->Options()->Partition() and this->Options()->NameSpace().

  2. Alternatively, we could just remove the function declarations of Partition() and NameSpace() and allow users to access those fields by calling Options()->Partition() and Options()->NameSpace(). This shouldn't harm any users, since anyone who has attempted to call NameSpace() or Partition() up until now would have gotten a linking error at compile time.

content.raw: +1 in a separate pull request.
content.html: +1 in a separate pull request.

content.raw: There's some missing doxygen here.
content.html: There's some missing doxygen here.

content.raw: For that matter, maybe we should consider renaming `TopicUtils::FullyQualifiedName` to `TopicUtils::FullyQualifiedTopicName`? We could do a tic-toc on it by deprecating `TopicUtils::FullyQualifiedName`.
content.html: For that matter, maybe we should consider renaming TopicUtils::FullyQualifiedName to TopicUtils::FullyQualifiedTopicName? We could do a tic-toc on it by deprecating TopicUtils::FullyQualifiedName.

content.raw: Agreed, maybe message type name is fine.
content.html: Agreed, maybe message type name is fine.

content.raw:
Oh, yes, we shouldn't refer to `TopicUtils::FullyQualifiedName` here.

Maybe it's not necessary to mention that the message type name should be fully-qualified? Perhaps that fact should be obvious?
content.html:
Oh, yes, we shouldn't refer to TopicUtils::FullyQualifiedName here.

Maybe it's not necessary to mention that the message type name should be fully-qualified? Perhaps that fact should be obvious?

content.raw: Never mind, when I saw `fully-qualified` I though that we had to pass the topic name as an argument. I see now that is only the type. Not sure if it's relevant the reference to `TopicUtils::FullyQualifiedName` then.
content.html: Never mind, when I saw fully-qualified I though that we had to pass the topic name as an argument. I see now that is only the type. Not sure if it's relevant the reference to TopicUtils::FullyQualifiedName then.

content.raw:
I implemented `RawPublish(~)` to be nearly identical to `Publish(~)` except that the processes of serializing and/or deserializing are reversed.

Is there something about the implementation of `RawPublish(~)` that causes it to behave differently than `Publish(~)` with respect to partition and namespace options?
content.html:
I implemented RawPublish(~) to be nearly identical to Publish(~) except that the processes of serializing and/or deserializing are reversed.

Is there something about the implementation of RawPublish(~) that causes it to behave differently than Publish(~) with respect to partition and namespace options?

content.raw: Could you also mention that this function will ignore any partition or namespace options previously set at the node level?
content.html: Could you also mention that this function will ignore any partition or namespace options previously set at the node level?

content.raw: Could you create an example of using this new functionality under `example/`?
content.html: Could you create an example of using this new functionality under example/?

content.raw: Thanks, d8d7392.
content.html: Thanks, d8d7392.
